update.description:
This adds the ability to save and restore dataframes.

When a dataframe is stored it is split into sequences each having it's own file. ~~The file format is hdf5 as this seems to be the only roundtripable format that pandas provides. To avoid confusion dataframes are stored with the ending ".df" .~~  The dataframe is saved in a messagepack file \(Pandas exported hdf5 files where not compatible across different python versions\).

Upon loading a check happens for any changes to the shot files since saving the dataframe. If changes happened these files are loaded regularly.
update.title: Save dataframes

content.raw: Silly mistakes. Should be fixed now.

To avoid confusion dataframes are stored with the ending ".df" .~~  The dataframe is saved in a messagepack file \(Pandas exported hdf5 files where not compatible across different python versions\).

Upon loading a check happens for any changes to the shot files since saving the dataframe. If changes happened these files are loaded regularly.
update.title: Save dataframes

content.raw:
Sorry for the delay. Seems good to me!

* There is non-standard indentation (2 spaces instead of 4) in lines 1480 to 1484.
* Is there a contradiction between the default file-open path ending in ".df" (line 2214), but the open dialog showing only ".msg" files?
* There is a comment typo on line 2239: desceing -> descending
content.html:
Sorry for the delay. Seems good to me!

  • There is non-standard indentation (2 spaces instead of 4) in lines 1480 to 1484.
  • Is there a contradiction between the default file-open path ending in ".df" (line 2214), but the open dialog showing only ".msg" files?
  • There is a comment typo on line 2239: desceing -> descending

content.raw: Just FYI: I'm deferring approving this pull request until Chris Billington comes back online.
content.html: Just FYI: I'm deferring approving this pull request until Chris Billington comes back online.

update.description:
This adds the ability to save and restore dataframes.

When a dataframe is stored it is split into sequences each having it's own file. 
The file format is hdf5 as this seems to be the only roundtrip able format that pandas provides. 
To avoid confusion dataframes are stored with the ending ".df" .

Upon loading a check happens for any changes to the shot files since saving the dataframe. If changes happened these files are loaded regularly.
update.title: Save dataframes

content.raw: Except for the check for changes in the files (wich is new) this is heavily used in our lab without problems until now. As it cuts down loading 2000 files from 2 minute to 5 seconds with the changes in the "Performance" pull request.
content.html: Except for the check for changes in the files (wich is new) this is heavily used in our lab without problems until now. As it cuts down loading 2000 files from 2 minute to 5 seconds with the changes in the "Performance" pull request.
